text: <@U02618EV1>: that was kickass
Ouch. <http://www.fastcodesign.com/3042408/why-samsung-design-stinks>

"Lee doesn’t see Samsung changing its corporate strategy any time soon, even with its new global head of design, Lee Don-tae (who hails from the same studio as Apple design god Jonathan Ive). So he thinks it’s up to some of those independent design studios—the ones that are cashing Samsung checks whether or not their concepts make it to market—to take their lumps in the interest of moving the dialogue forward."
<!channel>: has anyone seen the power adapter for the Nexus 6?

<@U02618EV1> - finally finished that wired article. I think Lee almost entirely wrong in his assessment. The problem with Samsung design is that Samsung doesn't know what it wants it's products to stand for.
Agreed. But I don't think that that and Lee's point are mutually exclusive.

They're not - but I think it's likely wishful thinking to imagine a scenario where an outside agency is able to produce consistently good work for a company that doesn't have a good sense of it's own identity

I read it too.  The elephant in the room is Samsung has reached $100B in sales by copying and iterating.  They are not innovators.  We don't have to look any further than Luxo to see how they operate - "Another company did something the industry seems excited about - we need to do that too."  That said, blaming Korean culture is a red herring.  I've worked with dozens of enormous American companies that are institutionally incapable of true innovation.   Almost all of them, to be honest.  By definition innovating means doing what hasn't been done. That means risk.  And risk is the last thing that is rewarded in 99% of organizations.
agreed 100% - this is much more a problem endemic to large corps than anything about Korean (or any other ) culture
the culture that's missing is one of understanding the relationship between what you're building and who you're building it for
We all know there is only one reason Apple is Apple.  If Steve hadn't come back and demanded innovation the brand probably wouldn't exist.
Absolutely. Two things really bothered me about this article: Focus on "vs Steve Jobs" mentality and the whole blame it on asian cultures subtext.
and not just innovation - focused innovation
Yes. I think focus is the keyword.
Yeah.  The reference to the famous grid is the most salient part of the article.  "Make two awesome products to serve two clearly defined consumers"

It's tough.  Samsung's success seems tied to their "shotgun approach" to releasing multiple versions of products, not one or two amazing ones.  I don't know how you change that point of view, since it's directly linked to profitability for them.

That said, do you guys think Samsung deserves credit for the "phablet" concept?  I ask because, at least to my mind, the iPhone 6 seemed like a reaction to the huge phones Samsung brought to market successfully (but tell me if I'm wrong).
Maybe - even a broken clock is right twice a day. But I think it's literally that: one of their creations finally hit
the likelihood that it was based on any sort of profound customer insight seems low to me. As does the likelihood that they could repeat it
all i know is that EVERYBODY in korea had a Samsung note. Not just employees. That was the main device for nearly everybody I saw
which I'd be curious to know how cultural customer insight drives anything they do. Not so much the hierarchical parts of the company, but do the people I saw want/need something else?

Yeah.  I'm not willing to give them credit for more than "dumb luck" with that trend, but what seems more interesting is that almighty Apple seems to be following, not leading (playing the "copycat/iteration" role that Samsung usually plays) with that product.
well - Apple does that a lot though
<@U0265G76F> That's an interesting point. Reminds me of Apple's push for bigger phones and how it seems to be helping them a LOT in Japan and China.
one of their greatest strengths is to see a trend, figure out how to make a great version of that, and releasing it
"my phone is too big for my hand" can now be a customer problem that drives wearable sales
funny <@U02F8TTPU>
Who needs innovation when you can always make it bigger? Worked with TVs and fast food.
<@U0260V4K1>: Definitely true.
woaaahhhh

In contrast to the Samsung article - I read this: <http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2015/02/23/shape-things-come?currentPage=all> over lunch and I think it speaks volumes to the difference between Samsung and Apple.

attachments.title: Jonathan Ive and the Future of Apple - The New Yorker
attachments.text: Inside the top-secret lab where the world’s most powerful design team created the Apple Watch.
attachments.fallback: The New Yorker: Jonathan Ive and the Future of Apple - The New Yorker

text: "Samsung Electronics sells vacuum cleaners as well as phones, and employs a thousand designers. Apple’s intentions can be revealed in one room. Each table serves a single product, or product part, or product concept; some of these objects are scheduled for manufacture; others might come to market in three or five years, or never."
look at all those people!

that way they have the entire summer to send it to Arizona
